title: The Shadow of Death

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on panel.

description:
This minutely detailed painting depicts the young Jesus stretching after his day’s labor in his father’s carpentry shop. His mother, kneeling behind him, looks up at the shadow her son casts on the rear wall, which seems to prefigure his crucifixion. Like other members of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, the art movement he helped found, William Holman Hunt was committed to direct observation of nature, and he sought to illustrate biblical subjects with archaeological exactitude.

This work is the third and final version of a composition the artist began in Palestine and Jerusalem in 1869, where he could study the setting from life. It was commissioned by the London dealers Thomas Agnew & Sons as the model for a print. The Art Institute’s collection also includes an early proof of that print.

The painting teems with symbolism. For example, the star-shaped aperture above the window recalls the light that guided the Magi to the newborn Jesus, while wood shavings and carpentry tools anticipate the instruments of his death, nails and a wooden cross. The bright red headdress in the lower-right corner foreshadows the crown of thorns he was forced to wear before his execution.
publication_history:
Argus, August 9, 1888, 11.

Argus, August 15, 1888, 5.

Leader, September 1, 1888, 11.

Argus, November 19, 1888, 8.

Official Record of the Centennial International Exhibition, Melbourne 1888-1889 (Melbourne: Sands and McDougall Limited, 1890), 640. 

William Holman Hunt, Pre-Raphaelitism and the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, vol. 2 (London: Macmillan & Co., 1905), 310, 382.

Evelyn Waugh, “The Only Pre-Raphaelite,” Spectator, Oct. 14, 1960, 567.

Oswald Doughty and John Robert Wahl, eds., Letters of Dante Gabriel Rossetti, vol. 3 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1967), 1152, no. 1319.

Walker Art Gallery, William Holman Hunt: An Exhibition Arranged by the Walker Art Gallery, exh. cat., (Liverpool: Elliott Bros & Yeoman, 1969), cat. 46, 49-51.

Theodore Crombie, “Round the Galleries: All the Changing Scenes,” Apollo 98 (July 1973): 49, fig. 2.

Günter Metken, Praraffaeliten, exh. cat. (Baden-Baden: Staatliche Kunsthalle, 1973), cat. 48, 96-97.

Thomas Agnew and Sons, Painting in England, 1630-1870, exh. cat. (London: Agnew and Sons Galleries, 1973), cat. 63, n.p. 

M. Davie, The Diaries of Evelyn Waugh, (1976), 738.

James H. Coombs, Anne M. Scott, et al., eds., A Pre-Raphaelite Friendship: The Correspondence of William Holman Hunt and John Lucas Tupper (Anne Arbor, MI: UMI Research Press, 1986), 182–83, 185–86, 190–91, 222, 236–37, 239, 244.

John Shaw, “£1.5m Price Expected for Hunt’s Masterpiece,” The Times, September 1, 1994, n.p.

Tom Sharratt, “Seeing Double: Shadow of Death,” Guardian, September 1, 1994, 5.

Geraldine Norman, “Hunt Replica Sells for Record £1.8m,” Independent, November 3, 1994, 6.

Alexandre Lafore, "Un chef-d’œuvre d’Holman Hunt pour Chicago," La Tribune de l'Art, Mar. 14, 2022.
exhibition_history:
Melbourne, The Centennial International Exhibition, Aug. 1, 1888-Mar. 9, 1889, cat. 51.

Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery, long term loan, 1905-1906.

Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery, long term loan, 1935-1973.

Liverpool, Walker Art Gallery, William Holman Hunt, Mar.-April 1969; London, Victoria and Albert Museum, May-June 1969, cat. 46.

London, Thomas Agnew and Sons, Painting in England, 1630-1870, June 5-Jul.13, 1973, cat. 63.

provenance_text: Commissioned by Thomas Agnew & Sons, London, March 1873; sold to John Heugh, London, December 8, 1873; sold, Christie’s, London, March 17, 1877, lot 56, to Thomas Agnew & Sons London [annotated sale catalogue; Agnew Stock Book, no. 295, National Gallery, London; in curatorial object file]; sold to John Throgmorton, Middlemore, Birmingham, England, December 23, 1896; bequeathed to the trustees of the Middlemore Estate, 1925; consigned to Thomas Agnew & Sons, London, June 5, 1973; sold to private collector, August 13, 1975; sold Sotheby’s, November 2, 1994, lot 172, to Lord Lloyd-Webber [sale catalogue in curatorial object file]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2021.
